title: Code Documentation Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of documentation practices and team communication.

questions.question: When is an inline code comment most valuable?

options.text: To describe what every line of code does
To explain WHY a non-obvious decision was made
To separate sections of code visually
To mark code that you wrote versus others

questions.explanation: The best comments explain 'why' rather than 'what'. Code should be self-documenting for the 'what'. Comments should capture context, business rules, or non-obvious trade-offs that aren't apparent from the code itself.

questions.question: Which commit message follows the Conventional Commits format?

options.text: fix(auth): resolve token refresh race condition

questions.explanation: Conventional Commits uses the format 'type(scope): description'. The type indicates the kind of change (feat, fix, docs, refactor), scope indicates the area affected, and the description is imperative and concise.

questions.question: A pull request description should only contain the ticket number, not a summary of changes.
questions.explanation: Good PR descriptions include context (why the change was made), a summary of what changed, testing steps, and screenshots for UI changes. The ticket number provides context but isn't sufficient on its own.

questions.question: What is an ADR (Architecture Decision Record)?

options.text: A document that captures an important architectural decision, its context, and consequences

questions.explanation: ADRs document significant technical decisions with their context, options considered, and rationale. They help future team members understand why things were built a certain way.

questions.question: Which is the best indicator that code needs a comment?

options.text: The function is longer than 10 lines
You used a clever regex or workaround that someone would need context to understand
The code uses a popular library

questions.explanation: Comments are valuable for non-obvious code: workarounds for browser bugs, complex regex patterns, performance optimizations with trade-offs, or business logic that can't be inferred from the code.
